Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Story: I glanced at my phone, my mother’s text blinking on the screen: “Dad’s not feeling well. Can you come home early?” I could almost hear the exhaustion in her words. My parents had been looking more worn out lately, and I knew they needed me—not just to help around the house, but to listen, to reassure them that things would be okay. But just as I was about to reply, my work phone buzzed. A customer was calling, her voice tense: “Where’s my package? It was supposed to arrive an hour ago.” I checked the tracking system and felt my stomach drop—the package was delayed, maybe even misplaced. I tried to keep my tone calm and professional, but my mind was racing. My parents needed me to be present, to show I cared. My job demanded I stay composed, solve the problem, and keep the customer satisfied. I could feel the pressure building, pulled between the urge to rush home and the responsibility to fix the delivery issue. My heart pounded as I stared at both phones, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more at that moment.
